summary: Detective Sherlock Holmes and Dr. John Watson join forces to investigate a mysterious murder at Buckingham Palace. It seems like an open-and-shut case as all signs point to Professor James Moriarty, the criminal mastermind and longtime nemesis of the crime-solving duo. When new twists and clues begin to emerge, the world's greatest sleuth and his trusted assistant must now use their legendary wits and ingenious methods to catch the killer before the queen becomes the next victim.

Reily as Dr Watson isn't better either. They both overact and scream at each other so much that is painful rather than funny. Also, its great cast is terribly wasted, is soundtrack is very out of place, its production is unremarkable, and its script is full with cringy jokes, baffling pop culture references and plot conveniences. It feels like a poor attempt at satirizing Guy Ritchie's Sherlock Holmes movies and a lazy copy of Steve Martin's Pink Panther movies. This may be the only time I do this, but I have only seen a few minutes of this movie here and there, and I have seen enough to rate it.  Every second of what I saw was so appallingly awful that it was literally unwatchable.  It's a slight slap in the face considering the fact that this came right after the tail-end of the absolutely brilliant 'Sherlock' series, quite possibly the most purely intellectual show of the past decade, and not too long after the passable if unexceptional Sherlock Holmes movies by Guy Ritchie, which were in themselves smarter than they might at first appear -- Now, those both did offer room for outright parody, but this just uses the characters and setting of Holms and Watson as a venire for the laziest and lowest-brow of humor.  It's tragic that John C Reilly, whom has shown to be a genuinely funny and likeably quirky talent, is tied up in this, as it's well below him, even moreso than Step Brothers.  Supposedly, this movie was offered to Netflix for ultra-cheap when it was completed, and Netflix said No, knowing that it wasn't worth the money to turn into a Netflix exclusive, and I have NO doubt that this could be true - it really is that laborious and unfunny.  Now, at the very least, I suppose I can't say that I'm outright insulted by this movie outside of how stupid it is; none of its content seemed to be mean-spirited or aggressive, but at the same time, watching paint dry isn't insulting either, and the drying paint is substantially less obnoxious.

Holmes & Watson is a comedic take on the iconic mystery series by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle. In this movie, Sherlock Holmes (Will Ferrell) and Dr. John Watson (John C. Reilly) are assigned to investigate the perpetrator of Queen Victoria's (Pam Ferris) future death on the Titanic. The murderer is their housekeeper Mrs. Hudson (Kelly Macdonald), who is a descendant of Dr. Moriarty (Ralph Fiennes), but don't expect me to analyze her plan because the movie doesn't care. Holmes & Watson is nothing but a barrage of predictable slapstick, insultingly deadly sexual jokes and painful meandering Victorian versions of modern-day references. Not to mention, there's an out-of-the-blue song sequence written by Alan Menken, who probably cashed his big paycheck for a pension fund and must have been ashamed penning such garbage. As for pop culture references, we get numerous allusions to Donald Trump's America, mentions of Fourth Wave feminism, and a cameo from Billy Zane at the end. Speaking of, the most insulting anachronism of all, aside from the drunken telegram sexting and the selfie from the Queen, the RMS Titanic was constructed in 1908 and launched in 1912, several years after Victoria's death. Not only that, the ship sailed not in London but in Southampton, tens of miles away. I know it's pointless to rag on a movie with nothing but comedic anachronism, but the Titanic ship is intentionally part of the storyline, one set in the nineteenth century where most Sherlock Holmes stories take place. Holmes & Watson is not only a downfall for Will Ferrell and John C. Reilly's careers, but also an insult to history, Arthur Conan Doyle's legacy and comedic intelligence. (1 Victorian Selfie out of 5)

It's fascinating reading the reviews on this movie. Clearly people either loathed it (most folks) or found it hilarious (a stalwart few.) I don't want to say that this movie was fantastic, but it wasn't bad, ya know? Sure there's some dumb pratfall and body fluids base humor that isn't my fav, but there is an actual plot of sorts, a twist, some funny moments, and some good one liners. The sets and costume are fantastic, a host of famous faces comprise the cast, and a modern spin on the very male-centric material of Artthur Conan Doyle give us several engaging female characters to enjoy. So. Why the hate? 

There are plenty of stupid, slapstick movies made every year, and most people don't wipe the walls with them. Why so many rotten tomatoes for this one? All I can think is that while there have been a number of "Bumbling Watsons" portrayed in Sherlock adaptations over the years, but this may be the very first Bumbling Holmes.  

Sherlock Holmes is a beloved iconic archetype, the brilliant sleuth, the dashing superhero who saves the day not with his otherworldly powers or great brawn (though the Guy Ritchie movies DID get more into Holmes' prowess at boxing) but with his amazing intellect. It does my heart good to think that perhaps people are simply offended at such an unflattering version of the famous detective. If so, I feel ya, fam. I don't really revel in seeing Holmes turned into a buffoon, but the whole movie is silly, many things are lampooned and this Holmes fits into this crazy world of topsy turvy idiocy just fine. It isn't meant to be a literary classic, it's funny and goofy, and spoofing, and for a laugh or two, it isn't bad. I give this flick one out of two thumbs up. Not destined to be a classic, but not as bad as everyone seems to be saying.

I quote Gutter from PCU: "I knew it was going to be bad. I did not know it was going to be this bad." This is the worst rating I have ever given a film, ever. It literally does not get worse than this. I can find absolutely nothing redeeming about it... zilch, zero, nada. When this was released in theaters and the abysmal reviews started pouring in, I had hoped it would be bad in a good way, or maybe even "so bad it's good". Alas, it's just bad… BAD BAD BAD all the way down to its core. It's not silly or shocking or anything that might appeal to certain niche audiences, it's just dull and lifeless and staggeringly unfunny. I did not crack a smile even once, and it was everything I could do to make it all the way to the end. I even primed the pump with a few glasses of wine before viewing, thinking it would put me in a better frame of mind to enjoy it, but it was all for naught. I've had stomach flu that I've enjoyed more than this movie. The film was clearly trying to parody Guy Ritchie's Sherlock Holmes films, and it's failure is beyond epic. It does not even rise to the level of stupid… to call this movie stupid would be an insult to stupid movies. Oftentimes, I appreciate and enjoy stupid movies, but this… this is a void of nothingness, the black hole of fun, the complete absence of entertainment. How the once fabulously hilarious Ferrell/Reilly collaboration has come to this, I will never understand - even their considerable comedic talents cannot polish this turd. This film is a cinematic abomination, an affront to all of the senses, a holocaust of humor. I beg you... spare yourself and do not see it.

I'm inclined to disagree with other reviewers, including both the audience and critics.  I found this fundamentally amusing and entertaining.  I am no prude with adult humor.  Was it clever per se?  I don't know, but I certainly got some good chuckles watching this.  It's not likely that I'll watch this again, but I give it more credit than most.  Will Ferrell and John C Reilly really did a good job acting in this.  They didn't hold anything back, and they deserve credit for their very funny performances.  Is this overall a shallow movie? Sure, but anything silly like this that gets me to laugh in this harsh world gets some valid credit from me.  Worth watching once when you truly have nothing else to do.

This film really isn't as bad as everyone is making out.  I think people are just offended because it is an American ridiculing a classic English character.  It has some great gags in it, mostly at the expense of the Victorians, but there are stabs at Guy Ritchie's film series.  I really liked the Victorian gym with the penny farthing cycling machines, and the exhibition with the first mobile phone.  There is great support from the likes of Steve Coogan and Kelly McDonald, and a cameo from Billy Zane.  I laughed out loud several times.  It's kind of like what Sherlock Holmes would be like if it were done by Mike Myers (Austin Powers) or Mel Brooks (Spaceballs, Young Frankenstein) so if you like that style of comedy give it a whirl.

Keep on walking.  I usually start these reviews with some sort of plot synopsis, but there isn't really one to speak of here.  Will Ferrell is Sherlock Holmes, and John C. Reilly is John Watson.  Moriarty wants to kill the queen, but that really doesn't come into play until about the halfway point.  I don't even really know where to begin with this mess.  I suppose that I knew something was rotten in Denmark when I learned that not even Netflix would buy the movie (seriously, look it up), and they pump out an Adam Sandler movie a year now.  I was groaning before the movie even started because I had a preconceived notion on what I was walking into.  I get no satisfaction in telling you that I was absolutely right.  I don't think anybody here can make excuses for being involved in this.  Every single person involved in this should know better, and they all deserve to get that talk from their parents: I'm not angry, I'm just very disappointed.  From talented actors like Ralph Finnes, Rebecca Hall and Kelly Macdonald, and even Ferrell and Reilly should be past roles like this at this point in their respective careers.  These aren't middle aged men anymore, they are both in their 50s, which is entirely too old to be playing these man-children.  Every joke gets stretched like chewing gum, and it is never enough to form any sort of story.  There are random anachronisms that never go anywhere that I guess are there to be funny, and they just keep hammering the same joke over and over... and over.  It's not on that same level as Disaster Movie or anything (because really, what is), but it's not all that far off.  I usually miss the end-of-the-year bad comedy that gets dumped in December as counter-programming to Oscar contenders.  This time around, my queue decided not to spare me.  They try to give a nod to Guy Ritchie's 2009 Sherlock with the slo-mo fighting, but they do it too often and incompetently for it to ever be funny.  There isn't even enough material here for a 6 minute SNL sketch, never mind a 90 minute feature.  It's not even a movie, it's just about 12 lame jokes that they keep punctuating until you're ready to throw something at the television.

For a moment I was trying to decide if Holmes and Watson is the worst movie I have ever seen. It was a brief moment. I have seen so many terrible B-movies and action flicks that amounted to fuck all, that this low-brow and forgettable piece of trash is quickly disqualified for that ignominious award. It's not even the worst thing Will Ferrell or John C. Reilly have put out. But it REALLY sticks in the craw for me in such a hateful manner. This movie fucked with the wrong loser.

Oh good God. There is no real plot here. Not that it mattered. No, this is a series of things that happen. Those things being two aging comedians screaming at each other like autistic children until someone yelled cut. The rough idea (I guess) was that someone REALLY wanted to satirize the Guy Ritchie directed Sherlock Holmes films with Robert Downey Jr. and Jude Law. Aside from the fact this movie is almost a decade too late on that front, it ignores the fact that those movies already WERE action comedies that had no problem making fun of their own premise and ridiculous steampunk tone. You were in on the joke AND you still had an interesting story and great chemistry between the main leads. And if you wanted a more serious and cerebral modern take on the classic character, you had the BBC series to fill your time. The other idea that led to this disaster was the history between Will Ferrell and John C. Reilly, which included cult favorites such as Talladega Nights and Step Brothers. And yeah that dynamic is there, buried beneath all the shit. There are a couple of jokes that work and Ferrell's English accent is not as terrible as one would assume.

But the rest is PAINFULLY unfunny. Aside from yelling all of their lines, overuse of the gag about Sherlock Holmes being able to calculate (or rather failing to calculate) the mathematics of a fight, jokes about how Watson REALLY wants to bang old Queen Victoria, there are numerous moments in which we are supposed to laugh at cocaine and heroin use. HEY GUYS! DID YOU KNOW THEY DID HARD DRUGS IN THE NINETEENTH CENTURY AND DIDN'T KNOW HOW DANGEROUS THEY WERE?! WIKIPEDIA SAID IT WAS IN THE BOOKS! PEOPLE IN OLDEN TIMES WERE SOOOOOO STUPID, UNLIKE NOW!!!

I think there is one teachable moment in this dumpster fire. In one scene, Holmes and Watson visit the morgue. Watson asks the World's Greatest Detective if he will be queasy again at the sight of dead bodies. It was at this moment the horror of this joke dawned on me. They are going to make Sherlock Holmes into a stock Will Farrell character for the sake of an overlong vomit joke. Sure enough, he vomits uncontrollably for the next five minutes and can't even get past the lobby. He then flirts with a mute woman and Watson hits on a doctor while they perform an erotic autopsy. What I'm getting at here, is that good satire operates within the rules and world of the IP or topic they are deconstructing. Sherlock Holmes has pulled apart corpses and put them back together for fun. He has spent many a night in rooms FILLED WITH THEM. You are telling me that no comedic writer can get mileage out of THAT weird shit? By acknowledging the source material (and actually understanding it) you can properly take it apart for laughs. For good examples of this, see Mel Brooks' filmography, The LEGO Batman movie, and the first Austin Powers entry. Needless to say, this was where this movie pretty much died for me, long before we have Queen Victoria performing an opening ceremony on the Titanic so we can get a Billy Zane joke. (Yep. That happened.) Fuck this movie. And fuck the people that made it. Netflix didn't want this piece of shit. Think about that. They had no choice but to release it into theaters knowing it would bomb on all fronts. Perhaps the use of the Titanic was appropriate after all.

Folks, I strongly recommend you do NOT see this bad attempt at a spoof of the well-known detective and medical doctor team.  After a few minutes I walked out of the theater, came back and asked for a refund, and got a pass.  What pray tell was so horrid about this travesty? Well, the opening wasn't that bad. The poor little boy Sherlock gets picked on. From there we progress to some absurd violent slapstic involving Holmes and Watson. Holmes is late to a trial where the judge has been making some inane absurd remarks about lowering his gavel.  Watson comes in and shoots up the place.  A couple bodies fall. He has made a point of shooting the clock. Holmes walks in, sets his hat on a railing, He is oblivious to its falling off, which is a cheap juvenile absurd way of making him look bad. I have had enough of this insulting absurdity. I stand up saying "This is the first movie I have ever walked out of. This is garbage, insulting garbage." Then I walk out.
This movie sucked big time!

Every person at some time has asked themselves: "How did anyone think this was funny?" Holmes and Watson will make you ask this question every 5 minutes. Most of the skits in the film have been done 10 times over and some of them were not funny the first time you saw them in earlier representations. The sad truth is Will Farrell is one of those comedians who is only funny 50% of the time. He needs help to be funny and it seems he got no help here. John C. Riley is in the same boat and as a result this ship sinks fast. Making it to the end of this film is very hard, so take my advice and go into watching this with low expectations. The lower you go the more possibility you might laugh, I'm not promising that though.

I love Will Ferrell and John C Reilly, and I am a Sherlock fan, so when I heard this movie was coming out, it was a no-brainer: I had to see it! Prior to going to see Holmes and Watson, my husband checked the reviews, and found most of them declaring "thumbs down", but, hey, EVERYONE I knew LOVED the Titanic movie when it came out, but by the time the main guy in Titanic was going under for the umpteenth time I was ready to push him down myself, so I chose not to judge the Holmes & Watson movie through comments... as I'm sure 'you' are wise enough to do. So, we went, and we laughed, and we got the jokes, and we got the sarcasm, we even got the "TRUMPed" remark, and we laughed again. The easily offended may walk away with their noses in the air, but we got the humour, and we laughed again! Needless to say, we're still Ferrell, Reilly, Holmes and Watson fans! 

I must say, Ralph Fiennes plays his part so well! The accent he uses stunned me; I never expected that accent to come out of his mouth. I loved it! :D Well done, Mr Fiennes!

And Kelly Macdonald!! Good call for Mrs Hudson. It was weird hearing her real accent, lol, but she was great, too!

Hugh Laurie, Pam Ferris, Rob Brydon, and Steve Coogan... What can I say; I love them all!!!!!! 

All in all, a  great cast, good plot, and a funny movie! I am hoping there will be a second one!

No one goes, or should go, to a Will Ferrel flick expecting high brow comedy, rife with clever dialogue, a deep plot, or expansive character development, no. One SHOULD go to this kind of film to drop the weight of their egos many often hide behind and just try to have a bit of fun, if only for an hour and a half. The film is fun and was made with the intention of being so, and since it did what was intended... I give 4 stars.

If this were made in 2007, in between Talladega Nights and Step Brothers, that Hugh Laurie cameo would have either been Vince Vaughn or Ben Stiller and it would have been all the better for it. Still, even if Holmes & Watson were to come out some eleven years ago it wouldn't have been directed by Adam McKay (the director of those aforementioned Ferrell and Reilly collaborations) and that is the chief issue with this rushed, lifeless,  excursion into a premise that never takes off; a skit that should have been cut not because of a lack of time, but because the premise wasn't near substantial enough to support the time it's given. 

As someone who turned 16 in 2003 and already adored Ferrell due to his SNL performances it was like seeing the rest of the world discover what I already knew that year when he delivered the one-two punch of Old School and Elf (I realize the former wasn't immediately seen as a success, but it's long since become a cult favorite). In the years that followed, Ferrell would go on to become a comedy titan thanks in large part to his collaborations with McKay-each of which are exceptional in their own right-but if Holmes & Watson signifies anything it is the end of an era; the final nail in the coffin that began being built a few years back with the likes of Get Hard and Daddy's Home, and continued through to last year with The House and a Daddy's Home sequel. In 2009, something like Land of the Lost was the exception, not the rule, but Ferrell has turned such expectations on their head and now we expect nothing less than cheap comedy from a guy who was once the king of being smart and cutting by being dumb and funny. Ferrell isn't the only one who has fallen prey to this plague of unfunny-friends in his "Frat Pack" have also had an equally tough time adapting their comedy and careers to their age as Stiller made Zoolander 2, Vaughn and Owen Wilson re-teamed for The Internship, and who knows where Luke Wilson has been for the last decade, but Ferrell's fall-for one reason or another-hurts a little more. 

Holmes & Watson is not a good movie and considering how good we know Ferrell and John C. Reilly can be together Holmes & Watson is even more disappointing, but it's not the out and out atrocity that's causing hoardes of walk-outs either. It has less than a handful of inspired comedic moments in a script where the same joke is repeated scene after scene to the same degree of effectiveness: little to none. A musical number that should have gone bigger and a zinger of a cameo, both near the end of the film, are easily the best things writer/director Etan Cohen's film has to offer. So, is Holmes & Watson a good movie? No. Was I ever bored to the point I didn't continue to hold out hope things might get better? No, not until the end came and I realized hope for Ferrell might forever be lost. At least until he gets a little older and redeems himself critically with more serious-minded work only to then make a glorious return to comedy and is subsequently discovered by a new generation of fans where the likes of Holmes & Watson will have long been forgotten and is never brought up again.

This was bad, so bad. Poor writing, poor acting, unfunny, etc.

The screenwriter obviously couldn't decide on whether this was going to be a period-piece comedy or something in the vein of the "_____ Movie" franchise. Modern references, including a Ghost movie pottery scene reference and Trump jokes, felt out of place and jarring, while major historical inaccuracies were abundant (eg. Queen Victoria on the Titantic before its maiden voyage even though it sunk 11 years after her death). 

The acting was poor too as it seemed like Will Farrell and John C. Reilly were phoning it in at times, while Ralph Fiennes was uncharacteristically weak. But the worst performance in the film, by far, came from Lauren Lapkus as she was insufferable. 

And the jokes were bad too, often derivative of things that I've seen in better films.

Spend you money on better entertainment and run far away from this movie.

The plot was simple and moved quickly, allowing for the pair to go about their adventure in a whimsical manner without too much focus on problem solving or anything too complicated. It was a plot made for old fashioned jokes. In their typical style, there was lots of shouting of humorous lines and strange facial expressions that could not fail but to make you giggle. The very well established role of will ferrel as an egotistical protagonist was not only maintained in the character of Sherlock but brilliantly juxtaposed by his faithful  friend Watson, who desperately sought Sherlockï¿ 1/2(TM)s approval.

The cameos in the film were a fun added extra for anyone who is a fan of such a thing, although I didnï¿ 1/2(TM)t find them particularly funny. They envoked a pleasant sense of familiarity and most definitely aided to the comedy, however  the duo led the way through the majority of the jokes.

The film was not perfect and it wasnï¿ 1/2(TM)t as belly achingly funny as step brothers, but MY GOD PEOPLE, chill out, be happy and open your mind to the film as being a couple of dudes doing some pretty silly jokes making for a hilarious hour and a half. Donï¿ 1/2(TM)t go in with expectations of a grandly comedic adaptation of the great Sherlock Holmes. No. It was definitely a mystery who the killer was, which is an important anecdote to make, but itï¿ 1/2(TM)s not meant to simulate Sherlock Holmes or your regular spoof. Itï¿ 1/2(TM)s a film and story all of its own, using the characters as a vehicle to create their own familiar spin comedy.

Go to the cinema, download it, wait for it to come on Netflix or whatever you like, but give it a chance. 

Remember, itï¿ 1/2(TM)s a film full of jokes so sit back and try and have a laugh!

Holmes and Watson does not offer high hopes going into it. The film currently sits at 6% on Rotten Tomatoes and at one point had the dreadful honour of being completely at 0%.

Watching it confirms the fact that it is entirely rotten. Which is an absolute shame. Will Ferrell and John C. Reilly are comedy greats and usually together their humour is multiplied...but clearly the problem lies in the script and direction.

Both duties fall under Etan Cohen, not to be confused with Joel and Ethan Coen and definitely not to be confused with Joel Cohen, writer of Garfield. Of all the Coen/Cohen's in Hollywood, we've found our Paul W.S. Anderson equivalent.Â 

Previously the filmmaker behind Ferrell vehicle Get Hard, it's amazing to see someone get worse, particularly this worse.Â 

Holmes and Watson has all the trappings of a Sherlock Holmes story and all the trappings of a potentially great comedy handled with the grace of the Running of the Bulls through the World's Largest China Shop. So inefficient and unfunny, it's definitely not great when you look around at the silence caused by the severe lack of jokes in the minutes before the opening credits (except one person in my screening, but there's always gonna be one intergalactic alien trying to fit in as a secret human).

The film is severely bland and lacking, full of choices that seem completely misguided. Ferrell decides to put on a strange accent for Holmes that doesn't work at all, and Reilly's Watson is overly and unfunnily violent, yet these are choices never dissuaded by the director, which is concerning.

Holmes and Watson has a story, if you can believe that, one where Moriarty (played by the criminally underused and probably overpaid Ralph Fiennes) has a presence, but is harshly pushed to the side in favour of an invisible antagonist you can figure out by spoilers by billing.Â 

On a completely unrelated note, Kelly MacDonald is in this movie and she continues to be brilliant and brilliantly Scottish in the things that she makes, and while her character is there for a bunch of anachronistic jokes and pushed to the side too, when her arc thins out it feels like it was a good idea made sour at the drop of a hat.

Somewhere, in this movie, there is a joke. I guess. I hope. Much like A Million Ways to Die in the West and other films of that ilk, the only thing that made me laugh was a heavy reference to a much better film that had humour in the fact it took you completely out of the movie you were watching, because it's safer.

Holmes and Watson is a hollow entry to round out the year of comedy movies. Alan Menken and Glenn Slater offer the second closest thing to a joke with an original song that's a parody of their work that's nothing compared to Vanelope's "I want" song parody in Ralph Breaks the Internet.Â 

Everything in this movie has been done better and bigger and funnier and smarter. Hell, even the overrated later episodes of BBC's Sherlock itself parodies itself better, even down to a drunk Sherlock scene that doesn't have to stoop so low as this movie does for an attempt of a laugh.

It joins a bunch of movies I would give no stars to if I could, but the sheer fact that somehow this movie made it from conception to the silver screen is some sort of commendation. Plus it has a Titanic joke that makes no sense, but it makes more sense than the entirety of the film.Â 

And before you say something, yes, the majority of jokes in this film are indeed out of time. And out of this world.

Which is not a good thing.Â

The onscreen chemistry between Will Ferrall and John C. Reilly makes this movie worth going to see. Our group of six showed up to the theatre to find the movie we went to see was sold out. It was either Holmes and Watson or an animated Marvel movie. Naturally, we opted for a comedic romp through Victorian England.

Holmes and Watson break all the rules that keep society together. They break all the rules on how white male landowners should conduct themselves by screaming at the top of their lungs for their female servant girl. The actress who plays the servant girl does a good job falling into the scene as she buttons up her gown and is followed around by whichever gent she was with when she was summoned by the unabashed crimes solvers. Then there is a American female doctor who has to prove herself to Holmes and Watson to be a doctor because there are no female Doctors in Victorian England. 

There are plenty of drug references to make fun of Sherlock Holmes  penchant for chasing the dragon. There are plenty of phallic jokes and opportunities for the characters to call each other wankers.  a wanker. Dr. House makes a special appearance as Holmes telepathic brother. How could they put Dr. Watson in the back with the elephant man? Billy Zane makes a surprise appearance as himself and he impresses on other ship boarders the size of his canoe. Holmes and Watson save the Titanic from sinking before it left England's shores to, well... sink. Ralph Fiennes plays the imposter and the real Dr. Moriarty. At the end, Dr. Moriarty is hiding out in Wyoming, leaving room for a sequel of Holmes and Watson hunting Dr. Moriarty in the Wild West. They have to wear a good disguise. Handle bar mustache will suffice

There are enough light hearted quips about Trump and American politics to have a sequel set in the West. England gave us our freedom, we should at least have a good USA sequel. If Holmes and his wrongly convicted counterpart (Holmes almost sends Dr. Watson to the gallows) can't save the Queen's life (despite killing her, they do save her in the end) at least they have a chance to make England great!

I quite enjoyed the film, and so took some thought to understand why the reviews have been so negative. Sure it's not a movie you're going to watch over and over again, but it got a few laughs, and both being British myself, as well as having seen previous Sherlock films, I was able to pick up on most of the references that may have been missed by the average viewer. I think the biggest downfall for this film is that the jokes do not hit a wide audience. The humour is particularly British, using British Slang and phrases. They also took some political agendas both British and American and made jokes of rather touchy subjects. 

In short, if you do not know much about Sherlock, England or Will Ferrell's type of humour, this movie is not for you.

This movie was bad. Really bad. This was like watching a Star Wars prequel, but less funny. As someone who loved Anchorman, Step Brothers, and Talladega Nights, I was severely let down by this turd. The more I think about why this movie sucks, the more I realize the key to a good Will Ferrell / John C Reilly movie is editing. Let the guys do their ad libs. Shoot hours and hours of footage. And then get a good editor to weave everything together into a 90 minute comedy. It was obvious that the editing sucked in this flick. The timing and pacing was off. The humor always seemed a beat behind. Hell...they should have edited the movie like they did the trailer. It was actually funnier than the film. If you're a huge, diehard fan of either Ferrell or Reilly and insist on seeing it, wait until the movie shows up on Netflix. For everyone else--just stay away.

Having seen the trailers on TV, I was most excited to see this movie. The trailers presented it as a fun, comedic take on a Sherlock Holmes story; that couldnï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)t have been further from the truth. Instead, the ï¿ 1/2 1/2comedyï¿ 1/2 1/2ï¿ 1/2Â? relied mostly on profanity and strayed so far from the realm of Sherlock Holmes that it was almost unrecognizable. Holmes and Watson also threw in some political jokes which could have been funny if not for the horribly akward timing and anachronistic basis. (Minor Spoiler) While on the subject of horribly awkward timing, the uncomfortable musical number made little sense and, therefore, got little laughs.

That being said, there were a few funny moments in this monstrosity of a movie. (Minor Spoiler) In a scene where the Queen of England supposedly dies while taking a self photograph (selfie), Holmes and Watson struggle to hide her body, gaining genuine laughs through the use of slapstick. In addition to this moment, there are a few other good laughs in there albeit, not many.

Overall, Holmes and Watson presents hackneyed humor and downright odd portrayals of the famous Sherlock Holmes and Dr. John Watson. By missing this movie, one misses absolutely nothing of importance, except for the bragging rights of saying one has made it through this thoroughly awful movie.

Sitting at a 0% on Rotten Tomatoes is a rare, but pretty terrible thing to have. Holmes and Watson currently is sitting at this legendary number, but is it really that bad? It's not good, but I didn't think this was absolutely the worst movie of 2018. From Director Etan Cohen who last brought us Get Hard (2015) Holmes and Watson is a comedic take on Sherlock Holmes and his partner Watson. Sherlock Holmes (Will Ferrell) and John Watson (John C Reilly) have just solved their most recent case revolving around the evil Dr. Moriarty (Ralph Fiennes) when the Queen (Pam Ferris) hires the duo to figure out a mystery surrounding a note saying the Queen will die within the week. Holmes and Watson are on the case and along with an American doctor named Grace Hart (Rebecca Hall) and her bumbling assistant Millie (Lauren Lapkus) they work to solve the case. This is literally the nicest I could have been here about the plot. It's incredibly simply, silly and predictable. Ferrell and Reilly have the same great chemistry they usually have, but its hindered with the whole Holmes and Watson personas. I almost feel like this would have worked better as an original tale and not as it was based on previous material. The movie is actually funny at times. It's incredibly dumb and maybe coming in with no expectations helped. I laughed a bit and enjoyed it overall. It's not perfect, or even particularly good. It has some moments that are funny, but this is definitely just a rental at best don't waste your time on this one in the theaters.
